page.title: 01Summary of area as a whole.
page.content: The villages on the northern edge of the{Mendip Hills}have long been associated with the mineral resources of the region. Coal was extracted from numerous small workings between {Mells}and {Coleford} during the 19th century, but the last pit closed down in 1927 and sadly, little remains of the surface buildings except at {Newbury, }and the undulated ground in Melcombe Wood and around Stock Hill. The remains of the{D.& S. Canal Branch line, which was to have carried coal to{Frome}can be seen in places at{Vobster} and at Coleford where the remains of the "noble and stupendous' {aquaduct" }as it was described in 1825 still stands today, encrusted in ivy and known locally as the "Hucky Duck". Todays riches are the pastureland of the many dairy farms and the limestone quarried near{Leigh-on-Mendip.
